text:
I'm currently applying for a graduate research fellowship with my university. As part of the application process, they want a CV. I have been an RA on *lots* of economics papers, but because of co-authorship norms in Economics, I am not a co-author on any of them.

As a result, I have never made a CV and only have a resume.

I'm currently going through and listing all the papers I have ever been an RA for and will list these, but am not sure how to structure the document as a whole. Does anyone have any advice for how to write a CV when you have lots of academic experience but no co-authorships?

text: Then I wouldn't worry about it. The CV should just say what projects you worked on, but mostly on your own stuff if economists are going to be reading this. It is a completely different system then the physical and natural sciences. They care about your own projects, not ones that you decided to do on the side as part of your training. Your the more junior professor is also likely to say (conditional on you doing a great job, which I have no doubt of!) that she or he would love to coauthor with you on future projects.

text:
If this is for a CV for something economists will read, then just don't worry too much. Nobody expects you to publish early in your degree (or at all! It isn't especially common) 
If there is a research proposal,that is what matters (and any letters from potential advisors) . Because they are funding you to do your own thing. And nobody expects you to have any good ideas until at least half way through a PhD.. Since it take 3 to 5 years to publish in top journals in economics, and everybody knows it... Plus it is really though to publish as a grad student (since you don't have your advisors name on the paper).

text: I'm with Jesse on this. At this stage, I would expect the CV to be no more than a single page. There is nothing wrong with that at all. If there is some sort of essay as part of the application, I'd focus your efforts there. Just make sure the CV looks good rather than filling it full of somewhat vacuous content.
